webTitle: Euro plunges on fears of banking crisis

fields.standfirst: Currency falls to 16-month low against sterling as Italy's UniCredit spells out risk of eurozone collapse
fields.body:
The Italian bank UniCredit warned its investors of the potential risk of a break-up of the single currency as the euro was battered to a 16-month low against the pound on anxiety about the health of eurozone governments and their banks.

Trading in the bank's shares was halted five times on Thursday because of huge falls as shareholders digested the terms on which it was trying to raise €7.5bn (£6.2bn) to plug a hole in its regulatory capital.

Italy's market regulator, Consob, said it was looking at whether short-selling rules had been broken because of the 30% fall in the shares in the 48 hours since the terms of the rights issue were announced. Short selling allows punters to make profits on falling share prices and has been prohibited in parts of Europe.

The anxiety about the banking sector and fears about the ability of eurozone governments to repay their debts drove the euro to its lowest level against the dollar since September 2010, an 11-year low versus the yen and a near 16-month low against sterling.

The prospectus issued by Unicredit – whose shares are at their lowest since its creation in 1998 – to entice its investors to support the €7.5bn cash call spelt out the possibility of a collapse of the eurozone. In a series of risk warnings that always accompany such share offerings, the bank said "concerns that the eurozone sovereign debt crisis could worsen may lead to the reintroduction of national currencies in one or more eurozone countries or, in particularly dire circumstances, the abandonment of the euro".

City sources believed this was the first time the warning – inserted by the army of lawyers working for the 27 banks underwriting the cash call – had been carried in such a document but would not be the last. However, the bank insisted that it was not predicting a collapse of the eurozone. The warning went on to say that "any deterioration of the political and socioeconomic situation in Greece, as well as a decision by the group to participate in restructuring plans for Greek debt could result in even bigger losses for the Group than those recorded on 30 September 2011".

The bank reported a €10.6bn loss for the third quarter as a result of writedowns on its holdings of sovereign debt. Its cash call – while expected – has knocked sentiment in the wider European banking sector. Germany's Deutsche Bank was caught up in the rout, falling 6%. Spain's banks were also unsettled by a Financial Times report saying its banks would need to make €50bn of provisions to cover further losses.

Federico Ghizzoni, the boss of UniCredit, insisted to Il Sole 24 Ore newspaper he was "optimistic" that the capital increase would be successful.

Even so, the plight of the banks put pressure on the euro, which was also affected by attempts by eurozone governments to issue new bonds. The euro fell to 82.50p, its lowest since mid-September 2010, and touched $1.2776.

While France raised €8bn smoothly on the markets, there was lingering anxiety about the strength of demand for the bonds. The 10-year borrowing costs for €4bn of bonds rose only slightly to 3.29% from 3.18%. Analysts at Capital Economics said: "The immediate focus is on concerns about the potential loss of France's AAA credit rating, which was reflected in another lacklustre bond auction."

Italy's borrowing costs were driven above the troublesome 7% level, while Hungary, where investors are alarmed by the risk of a debt default, was plunged into deeper financial crisis as its government was obliged to pay 9.96% for short-term debt and failed to raise the full amount it was seeking.

The currency, the forint, plunged to a fresh low against the euro, a damaging blow for many Hungarian mortgage borrowers who took on loans denominated in euros and Swiss francs. Analysts expect the country's central bank to raise interest rates for a third time in quick succession to 7.5% to try to defend the value of the forint.

Investors have been further concerned by the nationalist government's deteriorating relations with the European Union and the International Monetary Fund, both of which are concerned by a new law that appears to restrict the independence of the Hungarian central bank. Street protesters have also denounced the country's new constitution as undemocratic.

Hungary needs to raise about $16bn (£10bn) in the market this year to fund its deficit and meet its debt repayment schedule. Without access to financial markets at rates far lower than 10%, the need for outside support could become urgent. Tamás Fellegi, the Hungarian finance minister pledged to be constructive in talks with the IMF. "We are ready to negotiate without preconditions and we are ready to discuss everything at the negotiating table," he said.

Can holidaymakers cash in?

Should I buy my half-term holiday currency now?

If you are planning a half-term skiing holiday or a dash to Lanzarote for some winter sun, anyone buying their holiday money now will get more euros than they would have done at any time over the last 15 months. The €1.20 rate seen this week is the best its been for travellers since November 2008.

What about summer holiday cash? William Poole, FX Strategist at FC Exchange, suggested buying euros well in advance might be a good idea. "It's worth getting it while it's hot. The euro crisis will have to be resolved at some point and when that happens the euro will only strengthen again," he said.

In truth the amount you'll save by buying €1,000 now rather than in July at a lower rate is not huge. However, if you are making a significant purchase such as a house, now could well be the time to act. Foreign exchange firms will let you fix the rate now for delivery of the money up to a year in advance.

Meanwhile, if you are planning to go to Greece this summer, it is probably worth holding out. If Greece drops out of the euro, you will be getting a much better deal on the drachma come July.

webTitle: Dragon Peter Jones bids for Blacks Leisure

fields.standfirst: Dragons' Den star joins rivals JD Sports and Sports Direct in running to control struggling owner of Millets and Blacks outdoor goods chains
fields.body:
Dragons' Den star Peter Jones has joined the race to buy struggling outdoor goods retailer Blacks Leisure.

The telecoms entrepreneur is one of four parties to have declared "I'm in" and made an offer for the owner of the Millets and Blacks retail chains by Thursday's deadline. Leisurewear chain JD Sports and its rival Sports Direct, the group controlled by Newcastle United owner Mike Ashley, are the other known bidders.

Accountant KPMG, which is organising the process, will consider the offers before announcing a preferred bidder as early as Friday. Both KPMG and Blacks declined to comment.

The quartet are believed to be interested in acquiring the bulk of Blacks' 300 stores, which employ many of its 3,500 staff, as it undergoes a pre-pack administration. The process will see Blacks put into formal insolvency before emerging soon after under new ownership, following a pre-arranged sale.

Sports Direct, which owns a 21% stake, tried to buy the company last year and is its largest shareholder. Having amassed net debts of £36m, Blacks put itself up for sale in early December after deciding against a fundraising. Sports Direct decided days later not to make an offer for the Blacks shares, preferring to pick off assets once the group went into liquidation.

Other retailers, including The Edinburgh Woollen Mill, Go Outdoors and Mountain Warehouse, which were interested in acquiring only small numbers of stores, are understood to have dropped out of the bidding process.

The stricken retailer owns 98 Blacks outlets, 208 Millets branches and the Peter Storm and Eurohike brands.

Jones made his fortune in telecoms with Phones International Group, whose companies distributes handsets and resell airtime on mobile phone networks to business customers. Among his more successful investments from the show is the condiments maker Reggae Reggae Sauce. He is also on the board of online consumer electronics retailer Expansys.

webTitle: ENRC pays $1.25bn to settle dispute over Congo mining deal

fields.standfirst: First Quantum to be paid for its share in Kolwezi project and two other DRC mines in return for dropping legal claims
fields.body:
The London-listed mining company Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation (ENRC) is paying $1.25bn (£800m) to settle a long-running dispute with Canada's First Quantum Minerals over assets in Africa.

ENRC, listed on the London Stock Exchange, sparked uproar when it bought the Kolwezi copper mining project in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The operation had belonged to First Quantum but it had been seized by the DRC government, which accused the Canadians of contract violations.

City analysts said ENRC's action had alienated shareholders and several big investors, including Standard Life, sold their holdings in protest.

First Quantum launched international litigation against both the DRC and ENRC, claiming billions in compensation. But yesterday the dispute ended when ENRC agreed to pay $1.25bn over three years to First Quantum in return for its share in Kolwezi and two other mines it owns in the DRC. The deal means First Quantum will be left without any interests in the central African country that has been devastated by civil war.

The agreement was struck on the basis that First Quantum drops all legal claims against the DRC and ENRC; the DRC has also pledged to terminate its claims against First Quantum.

The DRC government, which has nationalised a number of copper mines, had said last year it would investigate First Quantum for what it called "suspected widescale misconduct".

Philip Pascall, chief executive of First Quantum, said the company was "satisfied that we have reached this agreement which we believe is in the interests of our shareholders".

The chief executive of ENRC, Felix Vulis, said: "We have gained assets and clarified the ownership of these mines; this will provide ENRC with an opportunity to acquire the underlying licences and ultimately to develop these projects, and discussions are currently under way."

ENRC was engulfed in another row last year when its Kazakh founders, who account for 42% of the shares, ousted two independent non-executives, one of whom later said the company was "more Soviet than City".

The company's corporate governance record has caught the attention of the prime minister David Cameron. In the summer, Eric Joyce, a Labour MP, raised concerns about ENRC's "shambles of corporate governance" at prime minister's questions. Cameron said he was aware of the problem and added: "When these companies come to London, they've got to understand we do have rules of corporate governance that need to be obeyed."

ENRC published the findings of a corporate governance review at the end of last year when it appointed a new non-executive, Terence Wilkinson, a former executive at Lonrho during the era of Tiny Rowland. But critics claim the company is still too close to the Kazakh founders.

webTitle: Union attacks Shell as it closes final-salary pension scheme in Britain

fields.standfirst: Shell is last of UK's big companies to scrap gold-plated retirement benefits plan for new staff joiners
fields.body:
Oil group Shell has written the last chapter in the history of gold-plated retirement benefits for future generations when it became the last of Britain's biggest companies to scrap its final-salary pension scheme for new entrants.

Shell is believed to be the last FTSE 100 company to allow new staff into its final-salary pension scheme after it said new joiners would be forced to accept a cheaper option after 2013.

A study by the Association of Consulting Actuaries published this week found that nine out of 10 private sector defined benefit schemes are now closed to new entrants and four out of 10 prevent existing staff building up further benefits.

The National Association of Pension Funds estimates that only 19% of private sector schemes are now open to new joiners, compared with 88% 10 years ago.

A spokesman for Shell said the change was made "to reflect market trends in the UK" and would take place in the first three months of next year. A defined contribution plan would replace the current scheme, which has £13bn of assets, though details of its contribution rates and benefits had yet to be agreed.

However, the Unite union, which has led a vigorous campaign against cuts to public sector pensions, condemned Shell for "turning the screw on workers".

Len McCluskey, Unite's general secretary, said: 'This is a disgraceful act, nothing less than greed on the part of one of the world's richest and most powerful corporations. They have no need whatsoever to close this scheme and in the process deny their employees the safe retirement they were promised they could save for.

"Shame on Shell, for where they lead, other corporates will follow."

The company has made large contributions to cut the deficit in its final-salary scheme in the last two years, pouring more than £2bn into the fund.

It has also increased its annual contribution rate for the £15bn fund covering Dutch workers to 45% of salary from 35%.

A small number of FTSE 100 businesses have continued to offer new staff entrants a defined benefit retirement plan, though at a lower level than traditional final-salary schemes. Tesco offers a retirement benefit based on a career average salary that leaves most workers only marginally worse off. Some large non British-listed firms offer final-salary plans, such as German car manufacturer BMW.

Defined contribution schemes are commonly linked to stock markets investments and pay out benefits based on contribution levels and investment returns.

Final-salary schemes disproportionately reward staff with the highest salaries at retirement age.

The pace of scheme closures has accelerated in the past decade in Britain, as rising life expectancy, coupled with poor market returns and the tightening of regulation has convinced company finance directors that they are unaffordable and have to be scrapped.

webTitle: Waitrose online orders rise 68% – and threaten Ocado

fields.bodyText: A festive surge in online sales at Waitrose has cast further doubt on the future of Ocado, a leading retail analyst has warned. Clive Black, analyst at Shore Capital, said executives at the grocery delivery company "must be very worried" about the momentum Waitrose is building in its online business. The John Lewis-owned supermarket reported a 68% rise in internet orders in the week before Christmas, and managing director Mark Price said he was committed to doubling online sales over the next few years. Price said the "phenomenal" growth in online sales helped drive the retailer to a "record-breaking" £200m of Christmas sales. Waitrose's fledgling online operation represents 3% of its total sales but Price said he is aiming to increase it to 5%-6%. The growth follows more than £20m worth of investment into Waitrose.com and packing facilities, including a "dark" supermarket where dedicated packers pull online orders from the shelves without customers getting in the way. Waitrose.com has also been boosted by the ending of a non-compete clause that, until last summer, prevented Waitrose from going head to head inside the M25 with Ocado, which also sells Waitrose-brand food. "We've long held the concern that as Waitrose builds online presence, Ocado will suffer," Black said. "We worry about the scope for a steady migration of Ocado customers to Waitrose as the main reason customers shopped at Ocado was to get Waitrose products." But he cautioned that it was difficult to extrapolate a long-term trend because Waitrose only released online data for one week of sales. While the number of orders rose by 68%, sales increased by 49% as new customers tend to make smaller purchases. Jonathan Pritchard, an analyst with Oriel Securities, said there was "absolutely no doubt" that Waitrose's surging online sales will hurt Ocado. Ocado, which was founded by three former Goldman Sachs bankers in 2002, has had a difficult start to life as a listed company. The shares, which debuted at 180p in July 2010, were the biggest faller in the FTSE 250 at one point on Thursday before closing down 0.65p to 57.2p. It is the UK's fourth biggest online supermarket behind Tesco, Sainsbury's and Asda. Price said Waitrose did well in the runup to Christmas because "if people want something extra special they come to us". Among its most popular lines, the retailer sold 2.4m Heston Blumenthal mince pies, 1.5m pigs in blankets and 9,000 pots of edible gold dust to decorate Delia Smith inspired cakes. Like-for-like sales in the five-week pre-Christmas period rose 3.8% compared with last year, or 9.5% including new stores and extensions. Turkey sales jumped by two-thirds and there was a big spike in demand for seafood, with sales of luxury seafood entrées up 217% and dressed lobster up 278%. Meanwhile, beleaguered retailers JJB Sports and Clinton Cards saw their share prices rise today after announcing better than expected Christmas sales figures. Shares in JJB Sports rallied by more than 33% as positive Christmas sales figures were released this morning. JJB, with 196 stores in the UK and Ireland, reported growth in like-for-like sales of 5% in the four weeks to Christmas. Clinton Cards reported an increase in like-for-like sales of 0.4% in the same period, helping its shares climb 2.27%. Investors were encouraged by Clinton boss Darcy Willson-Rymer's strategic reforms which he promises will encompass "real estate, customer service, efficencies within the companies and how we embrace digital". Expectations are high as the greetings card chain breaks into the world of e-commerce with its new online sales platform clintons.co.uk. Rivals such as Moonpig offer a range of personalisation options than ever before and Willson-Rymer, a former Starbucks executive, plans to compete with Clinton's own offering.

webTitle: Arm bucks falling FTSE 100, but eurozone worries continue to unsettle investors

fields.standfirst: Chipmaker climbs nearly 3% after upbeat broker note, but concerns over Italy send markets lower
fields.body:
As eurozone worries undermined the market once more, investors decided to turn to technology.

In particular, they were snapping up shares in chipmaker Arm, which added 15.5p to 610p following a buy note from analysts at UBS. The bank's Gareth Jenkins said he believed Arm's fourth quarter revenues could comfortably beat market forecasts by perhaps 6%. He pointed to a number of contracts which could come good in the near future, including chip designs for Broadcom's set top box and Microsoft tablets, as well as new deals with Samsung, Japan's Renesas and Apple. Looking further ahead, however, he warned of increased competition from Intel, particularly in the tablet and smartphone market.

But with the European debt crisis back in focus, the FTSE 100 fell 44.19 points to 5624.26 while France dropped more than 1% and Italy plunged 3.6%. News that Italian prime minister Mario Monti had made an unscheduled trip to Brussels added to the nervousness, as did the prospect of default in Hungary. Even positive US jobs data ahead of Friday's non-farm payroll numbers failed to help the mood, with Wall Street down more than 50 points by the time London closed.

A French bond auction was more or less successful, but more debt sales from Spain and Italy are due next week. Meanwhile the deeply discounted cash call by struggling Italian bank Unicredit continued to hit the financial sector. Barclays lost 4.7p to 183.65p while Royal Bank of Scotland was down 0.49p at 20.27p.

Angus Campbell, head of sales at Capital Spreads, said:

The New Year party has come to an end as the same old concerns continued to riddle the markets with fears that it's not just Europe's sovereigns that are in bad shape, but it's the banks as well which could cause the existing European recession to be longer and deeper than is currently feared.

Icap lost 15.8p to 329.1p after rival interdealer broker Tullett Prebon warned of continuing difficult trading conditions and UBS issued a sell note on the two. Tullett however recovered from its early losses to close 0.6p higher at 271.8p after a number of other analysts said the update had eased some concerns about the company's situation.

Heading higher was Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation, up 30.5p to 695p, after it resolved a legal row with Canada's First Quantum over projects in the Democratic Republic of Congo and paid $1.25bn for the disputed mines.

Positive comments from Morgan Stanley on UK property companies lifted Land Securities by 8p to 636.5p and British Land by 3.6p to 468.1p.

But Irish building materials group CRH - a recent new entry to the FTSE 100 - fell 43p to £12.42 after Credit Suisse lowered its recommendation from neutral to underperform.

Among the mid caps IT business Logica lost 4.35p to 65.95p following a downgrade by Bank of America/Merrill Lynch while International Personal Finance fell 8.9p to 172p after saying that it had hedged exchange rates for the bulk of its expected 2012 profits, but at a 17% worse rate than last year. One of the countries where it operates is currently in the eye of the euro storm, Hungary.

JJB Sports, up 2.1p to 7.7p, and Clinton Cards, ahead 0.5p at 11.5p, both performed in line with expectations, while Games Workshop, 40p better at 490p, said half year revenues had risen by £2.7m to £62.7m and profits had climbed from £6.8m to £9.5m. Peel Hunt raised its target price on Games Workshop from 550p to 600p and said:

We believe that the return to sales growth, combined with the high operational gearing, provides the rationale for an expansion in the rating. Furthermore 2012/13 brings a number of initiatives, including a 40k product launch and product to coincide with The Hobbit films as well as a Warhammer 40k MMORPG in due course. In addition the company continues to be highly cash generative.

Elsewhere oil and gas explorer Cove Energy climbed 12.25p to 124.75p after putting itself up for sale, with some analysts suggesting a price tag of around $1bn.

webTitle: Private sector jobs figures see a Christmas bonus

fields.standfirst: ADP poll shows December jobs growth was the largest monthly gain in a year, but numbers may be inflated
fields.body:
The US job market appeared to make a dramatic improvement in December, according to a widely watched poll of employers.

The US added 325,000 private-sector jobs in December, according to the latest survey by payroll giant Automatic Data Processing and consultancy firm Macroeconomic Advisers. The number was much better than economists were expecting. A Bloomberg survey prior to the report's release put estimates at 125,000 to 230,000.

The US Labour Department will releases its latest jobs figures on Friday amid further signs of steady improvement in US employment. On Thursday it said initial jobless claims fell by 15,000 to a seasonally adjusted 372,000 in the week ending December 31.

ADP's figures to not always tally with the government's, but the improving picture will be a major boost for president Barack Obama as unemployment and the economy emerge as the key issues of the 2012 election.

"December's advance was the largest monthly gain since December 2010, reflecting strong job creation across most industries," said Carlos Rodriguez, president and chief executive officer of ADP. "Small and medium-sized businesses were hiring at a similar pace. Job creation among large employers was also encouraging."

Economists cautioned that seasonal factors may have boosted ADP's figures and Friday's official government figures may not show such a dramatic improvement.

Paul Ashworth, chief US economist at Capital Economics, said last December's ADP survey had similarly shown an outsized rise that was followed by a more modest uptick in the government's figures. But he added that there was clear evidence that conditions were improving.

Last December, ADP reported initially that employment increased by 297,000. The official private payroll employment numbers increased by a more modest 113,000 when they were released a few days later.

"The upshot is that while other indicators do suggest that labour market conditions are improving, we would be very wary of reading too much into this ADP release. We continue to expect that the non-farm payroll figures will show a 150,000 increase in employment for December when the report is released this Friday," he said.

webTitle: Wall Street falls as positive US jobless figures fail to ease eurozone worries

fields.standfirst: Monthly jobs report a positive sign ahead of Friday's non-farm payrolls, but sovereign debt woes weigh on market
fields.body:
Better than expected US jobs data ahead of Friday's non-farm payrolls figure has done little to inspire the markets.

With the eurozone crisis once more at the forefront of investors' minds - Italian bond yields rising after Unicredit's deeply discounted cash call, Hungary staring at default if it cannot resolve its disputes with the IMF et al - shares on both sides of the Atlantic are heading south.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down around 100 points in early trading, while the FTSE 100 is off 38.09 points at 5630.36. Germany is down 1.4%, France almost 0.5% and Italy has plunged 3.76%.

So the positive US news is being ignored. Still, the monthly ADP report showed private employers added 325,000 in December, much higher than the 178,000 expected by the market. On top of that, initial weekly jobless claims fell by 15,000 to 372,000 last week. The figures could be a pointer to Friday's non-farm payroll number, which is currently expected to be a rise of around 150,000. Rob Carnell at ING Bank said:

The disparity of US data flow compared with the Eurozone has widened further, with a much stronger than expected December ADP survey. This ADP release is more consistent with our 180,000 payrolls increase than the 150,000 consensus view, and indeed, leaves our 180,000 figure looking rather conservative. Recent deviations between the household survey and the payrolls series could support a 300,000 payrolls number on Friday. Though the December ADP numbers are worth treating cautiously, with end of year adjustments introducing a source of seasonal error.

Among the day's other data, December sales in the US came in higher than forecast, although retailers had to discount stock to bring the customers in. The services purchasing managers index came in at 52.6 in December, slightly below expectations of 53 but higher than November's 52.

webTitle: Why Iran could start the next global recession

fields.bodyText: The oil cartel Opec is pumping more crude than at any time since late 2008. Europe is in deep crisis, the pace of activity in the global economy is easing, and the dollar is strong. Under these conditions, oil prices would normally be falling, yet the cost of crude has risen strongly in the first few days of 2012 and Brent crude was changing hands at just over $113 a barrel on Thursday, having been above $114 at one point. It's not hard to see why prices are hardening. The US and the European Union are threatening oil sanctions against Iran that may be triggered by the end of the month. Washington and Brussels believe tough action is needed in the dispute over Iran's nuclear programme, but there is a risk of collateral damage to the already shaky economies of the developed world. Iran is an important oil producer and exports around 2.3m barrels a day. The west has an assurance from Saudi Arabia that it will make up any shortfall from Iran, but as analysts from Commerzbank have noted, this would use up virtually all of the spare capacity from the world's biggest producer. The last time that happened, back in 2008, oil prices climbed to almost $150 a barrel. The expectation in western capitals is that the threat of sanctions will bring Tehran to heel, although there is not much sign yet of this happening. On the contrary, Iran is negotiating with China in the hope of finding a market for its crude (the Chinese, predictably enough, are driving a hard bargain) and is hinting at retaliatory action by threatening to block the strait of Hormuz, the strategically vital waterway at the tip of the Gulf, through which 70% of Opec's exports are transported. Although this appears to be merely sabre-rattling at this stage, even the hint of a supply problem from the Middle East has been enough to ensure that no oil trader wants to be short of crude. Strikes in Nigeria over the removal of gasoline subsidies have not helped the mood. What does all this mean? In the very short term, there is little prospect of crude prices coming down to the sort of levels that would be expected given the current state of global demand – $75 a barrel or thereabouts. On the contrary, there is a higher chance of Brent climbing above $120 a barrel than there is of it falling below $100. In the slightly longer term, much depends on who wins the game of chicken. If the Iranians tough it out and are prepared to risk military action with the west by closing the strait of Hormuz, the cost of crude could easily rocket above $150 a barrel. That would, without question, lead to a deep global recession in 2012. Policymakers in the west are banking on weaker inflationary pressure this year boosting real incomes, and have certainly not factored a serious oil shock into the equation. And, as every finance minister and central banker knows, each and every recession since 1973 has been associated with a sharp increase in the cost of crude.

webTitle: Hungary's woes provide yet another reason to worry about European banks

fields.standfirst: Hungary can't auction its debt, the forint is in freefall, protesters are on the street … and European banks are exposed again
fields.body:
It's time to get seriously worried about Hungary. Thursday's debt auction was a disaster. The country was obliged to pay 9.96% for short-term debt and didn't even raise the 45bn forints it was seeking via auction; it got just 35bn, presumably because it turned away bids pitched at 10% or more.

The backdrop is well known. The Hungarian currency is in freefall (down 18% against the euro in six months) despite rate hikes designed to shore up confidence and protect mortgage borrowers who have (ridiculously) taken out loans in foreign currencies. The government needs to raise about $16bn this year and Hungary's banks require foreign lines of credit. Protesters are on the street, raging against a new constitution that it widely criticised as anti-democratic. Prime minister Viktor Orbán's regime is at loggerheads with the European Union and the International Monetary Fund over a new law that limits the central bank's independence.

The only mildly encouraging news is that this auction disaster prompted a few conciliatory official noises towards the IMF. But there's clearly a very long way to travel before the IMF could be sufficiently reassured about the central bank's role to offer a financial backstop. Get set for more emergency rate rises to try to halt the flight of capital. The risk of a Hungarian banking crisis and credit freeze is high.

It's yet another reason to worry about the health of the European banking system. Eight of the top 20 lenders in Hungary are owned by Europeans, as the table below from National Australia Bank shows. The exposures are not huge as a percentage of the parent's total assets – but, nor, in several cases are they insignificant.

The combination of the Hungarian crisis and the mammoth rights issue from Italian banking giant Unicredit has put the skids under the euro.

The single currency, remarkably, spent most of last year meandering within a fairly tight range against the US dollar (which may say a lot about how poorly investors regard the financial health of the US) but in the ugly race, the spotlight is now firmly on the euro.

webTitle: More big firms defaulting on loans, Bank of England warns

fields.standfirst: Bank of England reports first rise in defaults by larger firms for two years, and warns that eurozone crisis is likely to make all kinds of borrowing increasingly difficult
fields.body:
Increasing numbers of larger companies are defaulting on their loans, the Bank of England warned on Thursday, as it revealed that the impact of the eurozone crisis may force banks to toughen lending rules for companies and households.

In a study of the fourth quarter of 2011, the Bank of England found that default rates on loans to large and medium-sized companies had risen for the first time since the end of 2009.

The Bank's quarterly credit conditions survey also reported that banks were warning that default rates by such firms were expected to go on increasing.

It said: "Lenders reported that default rates for secured and unsecured loans to households had fallen in the past three months, although default rates for unsecured loans were expected to stabilise in the coming quarter. For large and medium-sized corporates, default rates were reported to have picked up for the first time in two years and a further pickup was expected."

Lenders were experiencing little demand, and warned that the financial crisis would ultimately determine the level and price of loans. Households might also find it harder to get a mortgage.

The Bank said: "Although lenders expected a small increase in overall credit availability in the coming three months, factors such as the economic outlook and tighter wholesale funding conditions were expected to impact negatively on credit availability. Lenders commented that developments in the euro area and their impact on banks' funding conditions would be a key determinant of credit availability over the coming quarter."

Lenders told the Bank that they expected a "tightening of credit scoring criteria for granting new secured loans to households and a tightening of covenants on loans to large and medium-sized companies". They said that the increasing costs of raising money on the financial markets was forcing up the price of lending to large companies.

The Bank noted that while default rates on secured loans to households in the fourth quarter had fallen, lenders' expectations of potential losses should households start to default – so-called "losses given default" – were rising. "Some lenders noted the depressed housing market as a factor adversely impacting lenders' ability to recover any losses," the Bank of England said.

The survey indicated that times were getting tougher for some larger businesses, which lenders said were running out of "remedial actions" which might indicate that they had already taken steps to lay off staff or reduce costs. It said: "Across the corporate sector as a whole, a number of factors were expected to constrain corporate credit availability, including tighter wholesale funding conditions, the economic outlook and bank balance-sheet pressures. The survey showed the largest net balance of respondents reporting a negative impact of wholesale funding conditions on credit availability since 2007 – both for the past three months and the coming quarter – with lenders commenting that economic problems in the euro area had led to stressed conditions for funding markets and interbank lending."

The assessment may be a cause of alarm for the government, which is working on ways to get more credit flowing to small businesses through £20bn of guaranteed loans.

Simon Collins, global head of transactions and restructuring at KPMG, said: "For those in hope of a liquidity-fuelled recovery, today's report will disappoint … companies of all sizes are avoiding debt, both to reduce risk and because debt is expensive. They are refinancing where they must, but not borrowing to drive investment or M&A [mergers and acquisitions] activity.

"It's not surprising, but it confirms that borrowers are being rightly defensive – and that tends to be a self-fulfilling sign of low confidence in a recovery."

webTitle: ENRC settles dispute over Congo copper mine in $1.25bn deal

fields.standfirst: Row with Canada's First Quantum over DRC projects settled ahead of court case
fields.body:
Kazakh miner Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation has jumped more than 5% after it settled a row with a Canadian miner relating to assets in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

The dispute began last year when ENRC bought the rights for certain assets in the country including the Kolwezi copper project. First Quantum owned 65% of Kolwezi but says it was stripped of its rights by the DRC government. It filed a claim against ENRC in the British Virgin Islands and said it had taken this action "as part of its efforts to pursue its rights in relation to the unlawful expropriation of its legal title to the Kolwezi project." A court upheld First Quantum's $2bn damages claim in September, and it was expected to go to trial.

But now the two sides have come to a deal which involves ENRC paying $1.25bn for substantially all of First Quantum's assets in the country, as well as settling the legal actions. The deal is expected to be closed in February, and the news has lifted ENRC's shares 34.5p higher to 699p.

ENRC's chief executive Felix Vulis said:

We have gained material assets and clarified the ownership structures in order to facilitate maximum value creation for ENRC's shareholders, the DRC and its people.

webTitle: Services survey confuses economists … can we sound the recession all-clear?

fields.standfirst: Many economists will downplay the CIPS/Markit survey because it does not fit with their current world view – but none of us knows for sure what is happening out there
fields.body:
Everybody who writes about the economy for a living has their own "world view". There is no such thing as a totally dispassionate observer: all of us – me included - have opinions about the state of the nation and tend to make new pieces of evidence fit our preconceived theory. The tendency to do this explains why economics is not a hard science.

The latest snapshot from the CIPS/Markit of the UK services sector is a case in point. The survey was much stronger than forecasters had been expecting, showing a pickup in activity rather than the downward drift towards contraction. It certainly did not support the "world view" of most City institutions, which believe that the UK is on the brink of a double-dip recession.

As a result, there was a tendency to downplay the report by suggesting that the resilience suggested by CIPS/Markit was illusory and that the boost to activity will be temporary.

This may prove to be the case. The economy is certainly battling against some strong headwinds as we discovered when the Bank of England reported weak bank lending and the French government had difficulty selling its bonds at auction.

It also needs to be noted that this health check of the services sector excludes retailing – and reports from the high street indicate that trading conditions have been tough. Unemployment is rising and oil prices remain stubbornly high.

All that said, there is an alternative explanation, namely that the economy is actually a bit stronger than imagined. There are three reasons why that might be the case.

Firstly, we may be getting a lagged effect from almost three years of bank rate at 0.5%: cheap money is certainly reducing the cost of servicing a mortgage.

Secondly, monetary policy has been loosened in recent months since Threadneedle Street restarted its quantitative easing programme.

Thirdly, the UK is strong in internationally traded services to the US, and these have become even more competitive recently as a result of the drop in the value of the pound against the dollar.

Personally, I'd be wary of taking the CIPS/Markit survey at face value, and would want to see some "real" numbers from the Office for National Statistics before sounding the double-dip all clear. But it is worth putting the opposite case if only to acknowledge that none of us knows for sure what is happening out there.

webTitle: Shareholder group attacks bonus payments at property group Conygar

fields.standfirst: Investment group Conygar criticised over executive pay ahead of Thursday's annual meeting
fields.body:
Property investment group Conygar is expected to face tough questioning at its annual meeting on Thursday over executive bonus payments.

According to private shareholder group ShareSoc, the Aim-listed company paid a total of £12.8m to its directors in salaries and bonuses over the past five years, with the main element being bonuses. The executive scheme is designed to pay out 20% of any increase in net asset value, prompting shareholders to question how last year's bonus of £2.7m was calculated. ShareSoc said they were told the figure on which the bonus was based included £1.2m from share buybacks. ShareSoc said:

How does a share buy-back generate a profit (or improvement in net asset value)? Any cash on the balance sheet that is used to purchase shares should surely be treated as an adjustment to the capital so far as the bonus calculations are concerned?

ShareSoc advised voting against the remuneration report at this afternoon's meeting (see page 72 of annual report). Apparently large shareholders such as Aviva and Gartmore may also attend.

Meanwhile Conygar's have moved 1.5p higher to 97.5p after four of the company's directors added to their shareholdings by buying 1m shares between them at 96p each.

Update:

A spokesman for Conygar has responded about the buyback issue:

Conygar met with David Stredder from ShareSoc in the middle of December and explained that the effect of the share buy back, although very beneficial to shareholders, has been excluded from the bonus calculation, and matters relating to the conversion of the preference shares have also been excluded.

webTitle: Services PMI: what the economists say

fields.standfirst: Stronger-than-expected growth in the dominant services sector last month may have saved the UK economy from contraction in the final quarter of 2011
fields.body:
Vicky Redwood, chief UK economist at Capital Economics:

The UK CIPS/Markit report on services has followed the sister manufacturing report in improving in December — but the recovery still appears to have ground to a halt in Q4, while today's Bank of England's credit conditions survey suggests that weak bank lending will continue to hold back the economy.

A weighted average of the surveys over Q4 as a whole points to overall GDP doing little better than stagnating (while the falls in industrial production and services output in October suggest that a contraction is still possible).

And while it is positive that the surveys were at least moving in the right direction at the end of last year, we doubt that this can last. Note that in today's credit conditions survey lenders reported a drop in demand in for credit from both households and businesses and said that euro area developments were likely to impact negatively on credit availability in the coming months.

Jeremy Cook, chief economist at foreign exchange company, World First

Recent earnings releases from the high street have shown that demand was not spectacular into Christmas and I'm worried that this move higher may be simply a result of price discounting.

If that is the case it would be difficult to maintain into Q1. It would also make the potential fall-off in the first 3 months of 2012 that much more sharp, and increase the risk of negative figure for Q1 GDP. That being said, this number does mean that all 3 PMIs (services, manufacturing and construction) have been better than expected and this allows us to maintain our initial estimate of Q4 GDP at 0.1%. The pound has stayed at 14 month highs versus the euro following this news.

Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight

The December purchasing managers' survey provides some much needed, welcome news for the struggling UK economy. Given the dominant role of the services sector, the appreciable pick up in activity to a five-month high in December indicated by the purchasing managers significantly boosts hopes that the economy managed to avoid contracting in the fourth quarter, and could even have eked out marginal growth.

In fact our weighted composite index for the purchasing managers' services, manufacturing and construction surveys climbed to a five-month high of 53.5 in December from 51.6 in November and a 28-month low of 51.1 in October. This gives an average of 52.1 for the fourth quarter which is the weakest performance since the second quarter of 2009 but still modestly above the 50.0 level that indicates only flat activity.

However, it needs to be borne in mind that latest hard data from the Office for National Statistics shows that services output fell 0.7% month-on-month in October, so it will have needed a decent pick up in services activity in November and December for the sector to have grown in the fourth quarter. With manufacturing output clearly contracting in the fourth quarter and construction output likely to have expanded modestly, we suspect that GDP was essentially flat in the fourth quarter.

Alan Clarke, chief UK economist at Scotia Capital

The services sector CIPS survey posted a much stronger than expected increase in December, up by almost 2 points to 54.0 – the highest reading since July 2011. Taken in tandem with its manufacturing sector sibling that left the composite CIPS at 52.7 in December – also the highest since July.

In isolation the composite CIPS suggests that the economy will avoid a negative GDP print during Q4 (Chart 1). However, as we have highlighted earlier in the week, given the sharp fall in the ONS monthly services output data that actually feed into GDP, it is going to be very hard to avoid a contraction. Nonetheless, the buoyancy of this week's CIPS surveys does reassure that this contraction will be mild and short lived.

One mild concern is that the expectations component of the survey slumped by 4 points to the lowest level since September. That is typically a reliable guide to the next month's headline reading and is a warning not to get carried away by a single month's reading.

Our long held view has been that the period around the turn of the year will be the low-point for the economy. The squeeze on household real incomes is at its most intense now, but that should fade over the coming year as inflation subsides.

Similarly, the latest OBR projections showed that the extent of fiscal tightening in fiscal 2011-12 is expected to be roughly half as severe as the tightening experienced during 2011-12. The bottom line is that after a poor start to 2012, growth should be on an improving trajectory as the year progresses.

webTitle: Services sector bounces back in December

fields.standfirst: The CIPS survey showed growth was sustained throughout each month of 2011 and the latest rise in activity was driven by a 'solid increase in new business'
fields.body:
Stronger-than-expected growth in the dominant services sector last month may have saved the UK economy from contraction in the final quarter of 2011, a survey showed on Thursday.

The Markit/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) recorded a jump to 54 in December, up from 52.1 the previous month. This was significantly better than economists had expected and was driven by a "solid increase in new business" for the service sector, which accounts for 75% of the UK economy. Readings above 50 indicate growth in the economy.

Thursday's survey follows better than expected performances for manufacturing and construction, with the reading across all three sectors rising to 53.2 in December from 51.2 the previous month, the strongest expansion since July.

However, there is still doubt as to whether the UK can avoid slipping into a recession in coming months.

Markit chief economist Chris Williamson predicts the economy will show no growth in the final quarter of 2011 despite the improved performance in December.

"Faster growth of services and construction activity, alongside a stabilisation of manufacturing output, in December suggests the pace of economic growth accelerated slightly at the end of 2011. But growth over the fourth quarter as a whole looks likely to have been the weakest since the tail-end of the recession in the second quarter of 2009. The outlook also remains uncertain, reflected in historically low levels of business optimism for the year ahead," he said.

The jobs market in the sector, which accounts for around 75% of the UK's economic activity, was also subdued.

Markit said: "Employment was little moved, edging only slightly higher following two months of marginal contraction, while backlogs of work were reduced at a modest pace. December's fall in backlogs was the ninth in successive survey periods with a number of firms noting that new order growth was insufficient to test capacity at their units as 2011 drew to a close."

Alan Clarke, UK economist at Scotia Capital, said the buoyancy of surveys this week, including construction and manufacturing, should reassure the business community that a contraction over the winter months will be mild and short-lived.

webTitle: Tullett and Icap fall after update and analyst sell note

fields.standfirst: Interdealer brokers hit by concerns about falling volumes, as UBS expects cautious statement from Icap
fields.body:
Tullett Prebon and Icap are under pressure on worries about a difficult trading environment for the interdealer brokers.

In a trading update Tullett said the recent market volatility meant revenues for 2011 were likely to be flat on the previous year's £908.5m. It has taken action to cut costs, which will mean a £10m charge in the 2011 results, and further moves will be made in the first half of 2012.

The news has seen Tullet's shares fall 2.1p to 269.1p while bigger rival Icap is off 10.8p at 334.1p. They have not been helped by sell advice on both from UBS.

The bank's analysts warned Icap was likely to issue a cautious trading update on February 1:

Our interdealer broker volume proxy show volumes have declined 15% month on month and 5% year on year in December; this slowdown has been confirmed by [rival] BCG Partners which reduced guidance on December 19. We remain cautious on the interdealer brokers which we expect to be affected by bank deleveraging.

Singer Capital Markets was more positive however, maintaining a buy rating on Tullett:

Despite the woes in the banking sector and generally poor visibility plus an interest rate environment which is stagnant, the price of Tullett Prebon is discounting all of this in our view.

webTitle: Chipmaker Arm rises to top of FTSE on new product hopes

fields.standfirst: Analysts at UBS issue short term buy on Arm based on positive news to come
fields.body:
Arm, the chip designer, was one of the best performers of last year and is currently continuing its rising trajectory.

Its shares are up 21p at 615.5p, a 3.5% rise which makes it the biggest riser in the FTSE 100. Analysts at UBS reckon the company's fourth quarter revenues could beat consensus forecasts by around 6%, and they have issued a short term buy note on the business with a 620p price target:

[This reflects] imminent catalysts but longer-term remain neutral. Arm is rapidly growing into its multiple but we believe it will need to continue to do this before being more constructive long term.

Analyst Gareth Jenkins highlights a number of possible "catalysts" to come:

While it will be hard to top the news-flow of the prior two years (Microsoft Windows, big.LITTLE, 64 bit), we do see further positives to come including possible Broadcom set top box and Samsung Exynos (using Mali graphics) announcements, launch of 64-bit processors and, longer term, possibly Renesas for microcontrollers and Apple for Mali. In addition the rise of multi-processor chipsets should help support royalty rates.

But he sees some issues ahead, not least increased competition:

We believe Intel has accelerated its roadmap and will unveil its latest Medfield chipset for tablets/smart-phones with possible handset vendor support as early as CES [next week's consumer technology show in Las Vegas]. In addition, while Arm based Microsoft tablets are likely from the second half of 2012, we believe PCs will take longer reflecting the eco-system development required.

webTitle: JJB Sports and Clinton Cards jump after updates, while Blacks Leisure awaits bidders

fields.standfirst: Beleaguered retailers do better than expected, while four bidders said to be looking at Blacks
fields.body:
Two of Britain's more beleaguered retailers seem to have come up with the goods for a change.

JJB Sports, which came close to collapse last year and issued its latest profit warning in October, said like for like sales in December rose 5% and the all-important Christmas trading period had been in line with its expectations. Like for like sales in the second half of the year dropped 7.8%, but this was better than the 17.7% decline seen in the first six months. Chief executive Keith Jones said:

Our overall trading has improved in the second half and we achieved a Christmas trading performance broadly in line with expectations in the face of an extremely challenging consumer environment.

The ongoing credit squeeze on consumers and weaker UK employment numbers creates a tough environment. We continue to implement our turnaround aware of the importance of the periods of January sales, European football championships and London Olympics.

Shares in the company, which has been almost knocked for six by rival Mike Ashley's Sports Direct, have climbed 0.55p to 6.15p on the news. The near 10% rise should please Bill Gates, who happens to be one of the company's major shareholders. But many analysts are still unconvinced. Freddie George at Seymour Pierce said:

Following this update, we are retaining our 2012 estimated pre-tax loss of £60m and do not expect the company to beak-even until 2014 at best. We are also retaining our sell recommendation and reducing our price target from 7.5p to 5p. Although trading improved over Christmas against very easy comparatives, management, in our view, is running out of time to turn this business around. It needs to find a clear niche and a format, which is differentiated from its competitors to take advantage of the forthcoming sporting events. In the meantime, competition is intensifying, the cash position is a concern and the economic outlook does not look any better for the company's core customers.

Rival Blacks Leisure has added 11% to 1.25p ahead of today's deadline for offers, with four parties said to be interested, including Sports Direct and JD Sports.

Meanwhile Clinton Cards has climbed 1p to 12p after it said trading was in line with forecasts. Overall sales for the 22 weeks to the start of January fell 1.4% but in the final five weeks - including of course the festive season - sales rose 0.4%.

New chief executive Darcy Willson-Rymer, who joined from Starbucks, is carrying out a strategic review which he hopes to complete in the second quarter of the year.
